Definition: Large Language Model—a neural network trained on massive text data to predict and generate human language
Hint: A savant who's read every book ever written but sometimes confidently misremembers details

Definition: The neural network architecture underlying modern LLMs; processes all tokens in a sequence simultaneously using attention rather than one at a time
Hint: An orchestra conductor who can hear all instruments simultaneously, not one at a time

Definition: The mechanism that computes relevance scores between all positions in a sequence, letting the model focus on the most important parts of the input when generating each output
Hint: A spotlight operator deciding which actors on stage deserve focus right now

Definition: The basic unit an LLM processes—typically a word, subword, or character depending on the tokenizer (in English, roughly 4 characters ≈ 1 token)
Hint: Scrabble tiles—words broken into playable pieces

Definition: The process of splitting text into tokens that the model can process, using a learned vocabulary
Hint: Feeding a document through a paper shredder that cuts at specific intervals

Definition: The maximum number of tokens a model can process at once, including both input and output combined
Hint: A whiteboard that gets erased when you run out of space—only so much fits

Definition: The text input provided to a model to elicit a response
Hint: Whispering instructions to a genie before making your wish

Definition: Persistent background instructions that define how the model should behave throughout a conversation, typically set by the developer
Hint: The secret rulebook a new employee gets on day one that customers never see

Definition: A reusable prompt structure with placeholder variables that get filled in programmatically at runtime
Hint: A Mad Libs page with blanks to fill in

Definition: Asking a model to perform a task using only instructions, with no examples provided
Hint: Asking someone to cook Thai food when they've never seen a Thai recipe

Definition: Providing examples in your prompt to demonstrate the desired input-output pattern before asking the model to perform the task
Hint: Showing someone 3 photos before saying 'take a picture like these'

Definition: A prompting technique that instructs the model to reason through a problem step-by-step before giving a final answer, improving accuracy on complex tasks
Hint: A detective pinning clues on a board with string connecting them

Definition: The human's input turn in a conversation
Hint: A note slipped under the door

Definition: The model's response turn in a conversation
Hint: The reply slipped back

Definition: The sequence of previous messages in a conversation, passed to the model to maintain context
Hint: The stack of notes piling up on the floor

Definition: A parameter controlling output randomness; lower values (near 0) produce more focused, deterministic responses; higher values (near 1+) produce more varied, unpredictable outputs
Hint: A dial from 'play it safe' to 'get freaky'

Definition: Nucleus sampling—limits token selection to the smallest set of tokens whose cumulative probability exceeds p (e.g., 0.9), filtering out unlikely options while preserving diversity
Hint: A bouncer who only lets in guests from the VIP list until the club is 90% full

Definition: A sampling method that restricts the model to choosing only from the k highest-probability tokens at each step
Hint: I'll only consider my top 5 options, ignore the rest'

Definition: A specified string that signals the model to stop generating output when encountered (e.g., newlines, 'END', closing tags)
Hint: A safe word that ends the scene

Definition: The property where identical inputs produce identical outputs; achieved through temperature=0 and fixed random seeds
Hint: A vending machine—same button, same snack, every time

Definition: Model output constrained to a specific format like JSON, XML, or a schema, rather than free-form prose
Hint: A form with labeled boxes instead of a blank page

Definition: When a model generates plausible-sounding but factually incorrect or fabricated information with apparent confidence
Hint: A confident tour guide pointing at a building that doesn't exist

Definition: Techniques that anchor model responses to verified source material or real-time data, reducing hallucinations by requiring evidence
Hint: A journalist who shows you the receipt for every claim

Definition: The proportion of model outputs that are correct or match expected results across a test set
Hint: Darts clustered on the bullseye vs scattered across the board

Definition: A dense numerical vector that represents text (word, sentence, or document) in high-dimensional space, where semantic similarity corresponds to spatial proximity
Hint: Turning words into GPS coordinates so similar meanings are neighbors

Definition: A database optimized for storing embeddings and performing fast similarity searches using distance metrics like cosine similarity
Hint: A map where cities are organized by vibe, not geography—all beach towns cluster together

Definition: Splitting documents into smaller segments of appropriate size for embedding and retrieval, balancing context preservation with search granularity
Hint: Slicing a baguette into bite-sized pieces before serving

Definition: Descriptive attributes attached to chunks or documents (source, date, author, tags) enabling filtering and improving retrieval relevance
Hint: The nutrition label on the bread bag—not the bread itself, but info about it

Definition: Retrieval-Augmented Generation—a technique that retrieves relevant documents from an external source and includes them in the prompt to provide the model with current or specialized knowledge
Hint: A librarian sprinting to fetch books before answering your question

Definition: The component in a RAG system responsible for searching the knowledge base and returning the most relevant documents for a given query
Hint: A golden retriever bounding off to find the right tennis ball from a pile

Definition: A searchable collection of documents, data, or information that a model can query to augment its responses
Hint: The entire library the librarian can access

Definition: An AI system that can autonomously plan multi-step tasks, decide which tools to use, execute actions, and iterate based on results
Hint: A personal assistant with a credit card, phone, and permission to make decisions

Definition: The model's ability to generate structured requests to invoke external functions (APIs, databases, calculators) and incorporate the results into its response
Hint: Batman reaching for the right gadget on his utility belt

Definition: A predefined sequence of steps, decision points, or agent actions orchestrated to accomplish a complex task
Hint: An IKEA instruction manual—step 1, then step 2, then step 3

Definition: The process of passing input through a trained model to generate output; the production phase as opposed to training
Hint: The moment the magician actually performs the trick (not practice, the real show)

Definition: Deploying and hosting a model to handle inference requests, typically via an API endpoint, with considerations for scaling and reliability
Hint: The waiter carrying plates from kitchen to table

Definition: The time elapsed between sending a request and receiving the complete response, often measured as time-to-first-token (TTFT) or total response time
Hint: The pause after you order coffee before it appears in your hand

Definition: API cost structure based on the number of tokens processed, typically charged separately for input tokens and output tokens at different rates
Hint: Paying per brick used to build your house

Definition: Storing computed results (prompt prefixes, embeddings, or full responses) to serve repeated or similar requests faster and at lower cost
Hint: Keeping an umbrella by the door so you don't have to search for one when it rains

Definition: Additional training performed on a pre-trained model using task-specific or domain-specific data to customize its behavior, style, or knowledge
Hint: A pianist who learned classical but then took jazz lessons

Definition: Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback—a training technique where humans rate model outputs and those preferences are used to optimize the model's behavior toward more helpful, harmless, and honest responses
Hint: A dog learning tricks through treats and 'good boy!'

Definition: A standardized test suite used to evaluate and compare model performance across specific capabilities (e.g., MMLU for knowledge, HumanEval for coding)
Hint: The SAT for AI—standardized tests everyone takes to compare scores

Definition: Evaluations—systematic tests measuring model performance on specific tasks, used to track improvements, catch regressions, and compare models
Hint: Pop quizzes to check if the student actually learned the material

Definition: Personally Identifiable Information—data that can be used to identify an individual, such as names, email addresses, phone numbers, SSNs, or biometric data
Hint: The stuff in your wallet you'd panic about losing—ID, credit cards, SSN

Definition: Harmful, offensive, abusive, or inappropriate content in model outputs, including hate speech, threats, or explicit material
Hint: Sewage leaking into the water supply

Definition: An attack where malicious instructions are embedded in user input or external data sources to manipulate the model into ignoring its system prompt or performing unintended actions
Hint: A Trojan horse sneaking instructions past the gates

Definition: Safety mechanisms—rules, filters, or classifiers—that constrain model behavior to prevent harmful, off-topic, or policy-violating outputs
Hint: Bowling bumpers that keep the ball out of the gutter

Definition: Models capable of processing and/or generating multiple types of data (text, images, audio, video) within a single system
Hint: A person who can read, listen, and look at photos all at once

Definition: Converting visual input into text output, including tasks like image captioning, OCR, visual question answering, and scene description
Hint: A museum docent describing a painting to a blind visitor

Definition: Generating images from natural language descriptions using models like DALL-E, Midjourney, or Stable Diffusion
Hint: A courtroom sketch artist drawing from witness descriptions

Definition: Converting spoken audio into written text, also called automatic speech recognition (ASR)
Hint: A court stenographer typing every word spoken

Definition: Synthesizing natural-sounding spoken audio from written text input
Hint: An audiobook narrator bringing text to life
